channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: Fresh warning over rip-off locator forms on Google
item.description: 'Devious' sites which charge money for a free passenger locator form top search engine results.

item.title: Google app charges targeted by mass legal claim
item.description: A new legal action seeks compensation for all UK Android users who buy apps on Google Play.

item.title: Facebook warns growth set to slow 'significantly'
item.description: The technology giant said on Wednesday that the third and fourth quarters would see advertising sales drop.

item.title: Uber slides over reports SoftBank selling 45 million shares
item.description: Japan's SoftBank is selling the shares to cover losses in other investments, according to one report.

item.title: Covid-19: The pandemic explored in maps and data
item.description: Political scientist Dr Robert Muggah looks at the effects of the pandemic and national lockdowns.

item.title: Activision Blizzard staff walk out over harassment claims
item.description: Employees of the company behind Call of Duty are angry over allegations of sexism and harassment.

item.title: Intel chief warns of two-year chip shortage
item.description: Pat Gelsinger talks chip crisis, China and how the firm intends to fight back in the marketplace.

item.title: Ofcom appoints online safety head to take on big tech
item.description: Anna-Sophie Harling will have responsibility over how big technology companies regulate harmful speech.

item.title: Former eBay supervisor jailed for cyber-stalking critics
item.description: A former police captain turned eBay employee harassed critics of the online-auction company.

item.title: Shamook: Star Wars effects company ILM hires Mandalorian deepfaker
item.description: The artist, who uses the online alias Shamook, has been recruited by Industrial Light and Magic.

item.title: Oculus recalls Quest 2 headset pads after skin rashes
item.description: Quest 2 headset owners are urged to claim a free silicone cover to avoid skin issues.

item.title: Tech giants' profits soar as pandemic boom continues
item.description: Apple, Google parent company Alphabet and Microsoft report soaring quarterly profits.

item.title: Team BRIT’s Aaron Morgan: How hand controls help me race
item.description: The Team BRIT driver on how adapted cars help him compete in races against non-disabled drivers.

item.title: Vineyards set to go high tech with smart systems
item.description: Changing climate conditions and water shortages see some Australian wine growers turn to technology.

item.title: Beach rover picks up cigarette butts and other tech news
item.description: Jen Copestake looks at some of the best technology news stories of the week.

item.title: Cyber-flashing: 'I get explicit messages every day'
item.description: Influencer Elle Edwards lets us inside her DMs to show the extent of sexual abuse faced by women online.

item.title: Spyware: The software that watches you
item.description: BBC’s cyber reporter, Joe Tidy, agreed to be spied on to understand the spyware experience further.

item.title: Can better tech make video meetings less excruciating?
item.description: Technology firms are scrambling to add new features but will video calls improve.

item.title: Why remote working leaves us vulnerable to cyber-attacks
item.description: Experts warn working from home has led to complacency over security protocols

item.title: Covid: Will lockdown change England's new tech habits?
item.description: The pandemic brought about big changes in the way people use tech - the question is will they last?

item.title: What does a future-proofed home look like?
item.description: The technology exists to make homes more resilient to extreme weather, but it can be expensive.

item.title: Zoomtown-on-Sea? The lure of a new life on the coast
item.description: Remote working meant the Lancaster family could live anywhere - they found their sea view in Scarborough.

item.title: Pegasus scandal: Are we all becoming unknowing spies?
item.description: We may be stepping into a world in which we are all spies - and at the same time are all spied on.

item.title: Finding 'Grace': Murder, DNA and ancestry
item.description: How a novel use of DNA and ancestry websites is helping police uncover clues in cold case murders.

item.title: Why was my tweet about football labelled abusive?
item.description: A BBC journalist sets out to discover how Twitter moderates posts after he was banned from the platform.
